page.title: 16CUSTOMS LYTHE STIDDY
page.content: {CUSTOMS { {FIRING THE "STIDDY"} Firing the "stiddy" or anvil is a centuries old custom which signals a notable event in the history of the Normanby Family. The anvil is placed upside down on the common outside the blacksmith's shop. The hole is filled with gunpowder and sealed with a wooden plug which has a hole through its centre.The plug is tapped into place and the centre hole is filled with gunpowder leaving a little on the surface.This is then fired by touching it with a long iron rod, the end of which has been heated red hot in the blacksmith's forge.A loud explosion follows.The stiddy was last fired by MR.Len Jackson in honour of the Queen Mother who stayed in Lythe on 15th. July 1976.
